docs.lead_paragraph: A Wyoming college student who jumped to his death at a Denver hotel had eaten more of a marijuana cookie than was recommended by a seller, police records show — a finding that comes amid increased concern about the strength of popular pot edibles after Colorado became the first state to legalize recreational marijuana.

headline.main: Police: Student Ate More Pot Than Recommended
headline.print_headline: Police: Student Ate More Pot Than Recommended

docs.snippet: A Wyoming college student who jumped to his death at a Denver hotel had eaten more of a marijuana cookie than was recommended by a seller, police records show — a finding that comes amid increased concern about the strength of popular pot...

docs.lead_paragraph: Rates of heart attacks, strokes, kidney failure and amputations dropped over the past two decades, federal researchers said.

headline.main: For Diabetics, Health Risks Fall Sharply
headline.print_headline: For Diabetics, Health Risks Fall Sharply

docs.abstract: Study published in The New England Journal of Medicine reports that rates of heart attacks, strokes, kidney failure and amputations among diabetics have dropped by more than 60 percent from 1990 to 2010; attributes declines to better screening, medicines and care.
docs.snippet: Rates of heart attacks, strokes, kidney failure and amputations dropped over the past two decades, federal researchers said.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

byline.original: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and DENISE GRADY

docs.lead_paragraph: A report says that even as prescription costs have plummeted, a small slice of the population with serious illnesses is being asked to shoulder more of the cost of expensive treatments.

headline.main: Prices Soaring for Specialty Drugs, Researchers Find
headline.print_headline: Prices Soaring for Specialty Drugs, Researchers Find

docs.abstract: Report by IMS Institute for Healthcare Informatics, division of IMS Health, says that even as prescription drug costs have plummeted, small slice of population with serious illnesses is being asked to shoulder more of cost of expensive treatments; findings echo conclusions of other reports that predict spending on so-called specialty drugs will continue to rise.
docs.snippet: A report says that even as prescription costs have plummeted, a small slice of the population with serious illnesses is being asked to shoulder more of the cost of expensive treatments.
